channel.title: maGaming RSS Feed - kotaku_com
channel.description: A cleaned-up version of the original gaming feed for kotaku_com

item.title: Breath Of The Wild‚Äòs $180+ Vinyl Box Set Is A Test To See If Fans Want Physical Nintendo Soundtracks
item.content:encoded:
Good morning and good day. Welcome to Wednesday, perhaps the most meh day of the week. You ain‚Äôt not Friday, but you aren‚Äôt as bad as Monday. Anyway, welcome to latest edition of Morning Checkpoint, Kotaku‚Äòs daily roundup of gaming news and culture. Today, we‚Äôre looking at a cool new box set from Nintendo, checking in on the Game Awards, getting updates for games you can‚Äôt buy anymore, and remembering how cool Day of the Tentacle was and still is in 2025.

Nintendo‚Äôs $180+ Breath of the Wild vinyl soundtrack release is a test

On October 29, Nintendo announced a new 8-LP Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild soundtrack box set featuring 134 remastered songs. The newly announced soundtrack will be available in June 2026 and can be pre-ordered starting today. The box set will also include archival artwork created by the development team.

This is a rare move for Nintendo, which normally doesn‚Äôt release physical soundtracks for its games in the United States. But this new box set, as well as a cheaper double LP offering up 34 select tracks from the game, is being used as a way to ‚Äúgauge‚Äù how many people over here want something like this, according to Nintendo.

‚ÄúIn the Japanese market, CD is still a pretty prominent format there, and they do a lot of video game soundtracks on CD in Japan, and they‚Äôve been doing that for years and years,‚Äù Nintendo VP of player & product experience Bill Trinen told Variety. ‚ÄúHere in the U.S., we haven‚Äôt been releasing much in the way of physical soundtracks at all. And so partly, this is a little bit about us trying to gauge and understand what is the demand for physical soundtracks in the United States. Part of this is also simply an interest in trying to bring video game music to a broader audience, and it‚Äôs part of a few steps that we‚Äôve taken.‚Äù

Apple is now on the Game Awards advisory board

Apple‚Äôs gaming push continues, with the tech giant now becoming a member of the Game Awards advisory board alongside companies like Rockstar Games, Sony, EA, and Epic. VGC spotted the news via the official Game Awards website, which was recently updated to include Apple on the list of board members. To be clear, the advisory board doesn‚Äôt have any involvement in what games are nominated, or which ones win. So Apple won‚Äôt be helping pick this year‚Äôs Game of the Year at Geoff Keighley‚Äôs annual trailer extravaganza (featuring some awards), but it will be rubbing elbows with more of the gaming industry. How many Apple Arcade commercials will we see this year? My bet is at least two!

Super Mario 3D All-Stars gets another Switch 2 update, still not for sale again

Remember Super Mario 3D All-Stars? It was that awesome collection of 3D Mario games‚ÄîSM64, Galaxy, and Sunshine‚Äîthat Nintendo launched in 2020. And then stopped selling after just six months as part of a limited-time celebration of the franchise‚Äôs 35th anniversary. Five years later, Nintendo still hasn‚Äôt made the games available again to buy on its store (well, except for Galaxy which recently got a remaster that costs $40 all by itself). But if you do own 3D All-Stars, good news: It just got another update to help it run better on Switch 2. This keeps happening, with the collection getting an update in July, and it‚Äôs extremely frustrating. Why is this package not available to buy on Switch and Switch 2 in 2025? Come on, Nintendo, let people give you money.

The Resident Evil 2 remake has now sold over 16 million copies

The best-selling Resident Evil game continues to sell well. Resident Evil 2 remake has now sold over 16 million copies, according to Capcom‚Äôs latest financial report. But interestingly, Resident Evil 7 Biohazard is catching up. This latest report shows the soft reboot of the horror franchise has now reached 15.9 million copies sold. With Resident Evil 7 making the leap to Switch 2 in 2026, it‚Äôs likely that this entry might overtake the RE2 remake to become the biggest game in the survival horror series.

ICYMI:

  • Battlefield 6‚Ä≤s new map isn‚Äôt very good and feels too small
  • Amazon is scaling down its gaming plans and laying off thousands
  • Check out our Hollow Knight: Silksong review

Watch This:



https://kotaku.com/breath-of-the-wilds-zelda-record-box-set-price-nintendo-apple-mario-update-switch-2-2000639847

item.title: This Guy Is The Unsung Hero Of Pok√©mon Legends: Z-A
item.content:encoded:
One of the best parts of Pok√©mon Legends: Z-A is that its single-city setting illustrates the power of community building and the importance of public services. Its cast of trainers come from different walks of life and all contribute something different to Lumiose City. However, we‚Äôre not here to talk about the streamer, socialite, or mob boss. We‚Äôre here to talk about the true backbone of Lumiose City‚Äôs urban redevelopment plan: the Pok√© Ball Collector.

These unnamed men show up throughout Lumiose, typically next to a Pok√©mon Center, and if you ever see them with a yellow text bubble above their heads, you should talk to them immediately. See, these handsome gentlemen are part of the city‚Äôs clean-up crew, but they focus on a specific type of trash littered around town: Pok√© Balls. Every time you misthrow one of these capture devices at the local wildlife, these guys are right behind you, collecting these relics of your Pok√©mon training failures to give them back to you so you don‚Äôt have to buy more balls when perfectly good ones are lying around the Wild Zones. 

Crucially, he will only pick up ones that miss their target, not ones that fail to capture a Pok√©mon because you didn‚Äôt weaken them enough in battle. But even so, that‚Äôs such a handy quality-of-life change that I‚Äôm surprised it took Pok√©mon nearly 30 years to implement. I guess it works best when your game is set in one city, and thus it makes sense to have dedicated systems and workers who can devote their shifts to this. But it‚Äôs especially helpful in a Legends game in which you throw Pok√© Balls manually and can miss your target if you‚Äôre carelessly tossing them.

Now these collectors are amassing a ton of fans, and I wouldn‚Äôt be surprised if we saw them featured in other Pok√©mon media moving forward. A guy who picks up garbage and brings it back to you is just waiting for a trading card that lets you pick through your discard pile.

the true hero of Pok√©mon Legends: Z-A pic.twitter.com/zGdGYjNOcs

‚Äî Out of Context Pok√©mon (@OoCPokemon) October 26, 2025

i am not good at this game pic.twitter.com/eVJzmun6n3

‚Äî Dyylas (@DylanDyylas) October 26, 2025

When nobody else got me I know unnamed ball collector man got me https://t.co/SjifPJR3zq pic.twitter.com/tuPLZWvU8w

‚Äî skipppppy üçâ/COMMS OPEN!!/ (@skipppppy_art) October 25, 2025

EXTREMELY IMPORTANT UPDATE:

HIS NAME IS LEANDRO AND HE LIKES ELECTRIC TYPES https://t.co/eOvZX2exvl pic.twitter.com/ttIRJOfVam

‚Äî skipppppy üçâ/COMMS OPEN!!/ (@skipppppy_art) October 28, 2025

As far as I‚Äôm concerned, Pok√© Ball collectors need to become a new standard for the series alongside Nurse Joy. A whole new job market has opened in the Pok√©mon world, and Game Freak better keep these guys employed.



https://kotaku.com/pokemon-legends-za-poke-ball-collector-locations-center-2000639858

item.title: 12 Things I Wish I Knew Before Playing Escape From Duckov
item.content:encoded:
I very heartily recommend you play extraction shooter Escape from Duckov. Do no be fooled by the silly name or cartoony presentation: this is a very in-depth game with an enormous number of mechanics to get to grips with, especially if you‚Äôre newer to the looter-shooter format. But fear not, for I have spent so very many hours making so very many mistakes that I am now expertly placed to warn you how not to follow in my footsteps. Here are 12 things I wish I knew before playing Escape from Duckov.

You‚Äôre going to die, a lot, and that‚Äôs OK

Your goal in Escape from Duckov is to explore an overworld populated by murderous ducks, in order to loot the equipment you need to build up your base, improve your weapons and armor, and head off ever-further in pursuit of new quests. However, on each and every trip, you‚Äôre risking absolutely everything you‚Äôre taking with you, alongside anything you pick up on your way. While many extraction shooters play out as multiplayer PvP games, where loss of progress feels far more normal, Escape from Duckov is a purely single-player shooter. This can make the losses almost unbearable until you develop a zen-like approach to failure. Because you will fail.

Every trip is fraught, with the overworld‚Äôs population of enemies changing each time you head up there. The enormous explorable areas maintain the same layout, albeit with lockers and chests in varying places, but where certain gangs of marauding ducks hang out can change, along with the spots where you might find a few named boss types. Let your guard down and you can be easily ambushed. Venture too far with not enough first aid and you can be easily taken down. Bring the wrong ammo type for your current weapons and you can find yourself helpless. Or just completely goof up and let a hand grenade explode at your feet and you‚Äôre also done for. The point is, you‚Äôll die.

You‚Äôve got one chance to get your stuff back

Now, you do get one chance to recover your lost items. Every death returns you to your base, your character inventory almost emptied, and your spirit dented. But fear not: everything you died with is still up there, next to the site of your death. All you need to do is head back up and grab it! Except, remember why you died? That‚Äôs likely to still be a problem. And if you die again before you pick it all up, then it‚Äôs all gone forever*. So you can‚Äôt just be running back up there in your duck underwear and hope you‚Äôll be fine. You‚Äôll always want to make sure you have back-ups of vital equipment like armor, weapons and ammo stashed in your base‚Äôs enormous warehouse.

Even then, don‚Äôt get cocky. Think of this trip as a recovery only, no matter how tempted you might be to tick off another quest en route, or take an extra risk for the sake of some big loot. Mess this up and all your best equipment is gone-gone. It‚Äôs about getting in and out, ideally without ever being seen. Find your death site, move everything over as quickly as you can, and then extract at the nearest exit. Anything else is hubris, and believe me, you will need to close the game down and take a walk if you screw this up because you didn‚Äôt focus.

*OK, there‚Äôs a way to save scum

Yes, OK, it‚Äôs not necessarily gone-gone. There is a rather scummy way to get your stuff back if you‚Äôre willing. So long as you‚Äôre prompt (usually within one real-world hour) after you last had the equipment, you can return to the main menu, choose your save slot, and then click ‚ÄúRestore Backup‚Äù in the bottom right. This lets you pick from the last ten autosaves you never knew the game was making and overwrite your current position. It‚Äôs obviously cheating, and I really recommend against it: a lot of the fun of Duckov is facing up to those losses, and rebuilding from meager parts with a few early-stage runs to gather equipment for crafting what you‚Äôve lost. But then again, no one else will ever know.

You want to increase your carrying capacity ASAP

For a game with 48 billion-trillion pieces of loot to gather, Duckov doesn‚Äôt give you a lot of space to carry them. By default you have 22 slots in your inventory, which will very quickly be taken up by spare weapons, various types of ammo, first aid, and food and drink, and that‚Äôs before you‚Äôre vacuuming up the items in the overworld. Some loot stacks, other loot doesn‚Äôt, and juggling what you can carry is a constant concern. So the first thing you want to do is add space.

The easiest way to do this is with the various bags you can find and craft. The first of these, a make-up pouch, adds a very welcome extra row of inventory slots, but you‚Äôll almost immediately be craving more. As you explore further out, you‚Äôll find larger bags that not only add an abundance of new slots, but also increase the total weight you can carry before you become encumbered. But bags are only the start.

It‚Äôs always worth noticing what various bits of armor can do for you here, too. You‚Äôll usually have to sacrifice extra protection for larger numbers of extra slots, but body armor can give you a very welcome handful of additional spaces. The game also has slightly mystical items called Totems, two of which you can wear at any time that will augment various abilities and defenses. One of these is called Sturdy, which at level 2 will boost your inventory slots by 25 percent.

There‚Äôs a quick way to get more totems

Speaking of Totems, something Duckov absolutely does not make clear is that there‚Äôs a quick way to access more of them via some peculiar incantations in the sewers. In the top right corner of your base is a hatch that leads down to some sewers below. From here you can reach a ‚Äúsecret‚Äù passage to a location in the first overground area, and a boat that‚Äôll take you to town once you can find or afford the tickets. But there‚Äôs also an odd little area with chalk circles on the floor. If you‚Äôve played at all, you‚Äôll notice you‚Äôre picking up an awful lot of Fading Feathers from your killed enemies, and while selling these can get you some much-needed cash, saving them up also offers this big benefit. Because down here you can ‚Äúsacrifice‚Äù them, eight or 80 at a time, in exchange for random Totems.

What you get is very unpredictable, but it can be game-changing. That Sturdy II I mentioned was something I got this way, and it‚Äôs made such a difference. Others will improve your health, your armor, stamina limits, perception ability (the cone of sight in which you can spot enemies), and how your guns work. It‚Äôs nightmarish picking only two to wear at a time, honestly, but the more choice the better.

Night is not quite as bad as the game suggests

If you try to leave your base anywhere close to dusk, the game will warn you that it might be a better idea to sleep the night away rather than risk the increased danger. And right at the start, that‚Äôs advice worth listening to. But it won‚Äôt stop warning you, even when you‚Äôre ready. Once you feel comfortable with some solid armor and powerful weapons, you can begin to brave the dark. The difference is robo-spiders, which come out at night and are very powerful foes. But not crazy tough, and if you make sure to use cover and quality ammo, you‚Äôll mow them down quickly enough. And their robotic cores are key to unlocking a lot of the mid-game goodies.

Your doggy chum has no weight limit

Accompanying you on your expeditions is a little, loyal pup. He doesn‚Äôt seem to do anything at all, until you notice he‚Äôs capable of carrying stuff. As you upgrade various elements, you can increase these slots to two or three after a fair few hours, and they prove to be super useful. Firstly, anything your doggo is carrying isn‚Äôt lost when you die. Presumably he bravely scampers back to your hideout with whatever you gave him. This means he‚Äôs ideal for carrying items you must never lose, like the key pouch you can find that‚Äôll hold all sorts of keys and paper passes whose loss would be awful. Like, the worst. Hideous. Yes, I literally just did it. I swapped out the Key Case for a super-heavy set of body armor I wanted to bring back as spare, and then everything went horrible wrong.

However, my stupidity aside, the dog is also fantastic for its apparent infinite strength. Often, even when you‚Äôve more inventory slots than you need, you‚Äôll find yourself over-encumbered as higher level weapons and armor start to weigh four or five kilograms each. But hand them over to dog-chum and they‚Äôre out of your inventory, and he‚Äôs unbothered. Just remember to also take them back off him when you get back to base. I am embarrassed by how many times I‚Äôve set off on a new trip with the poor thing already carrying a massive plastic barrel and a set of level 5 armor.

Storms are a real pain

Every few hundred hours (which translate to real-world minutes) the overworld is consumed by a peculiar purple storm. And it will kill you in seconds. For the longest time, there‚Äôs simply no way around this. You might stumble on some injections that purport to help early on, but don‚Äôt even try. You‚Äôre going to have been playing for a hefty length of time before braving storms is even worth considering, with specialist armor and equipment. In the meantime, just sleep your way past them.

Frequently check your Build station

Your base begins with a Build station, represented by what looks like a large blueprint on a stand, and it‚Äôs via this that you‚Äôll learn what loot you need to build the many stations that will fill your base. But it also occasionally adds new and very useful builds without bothering to tell you. It‚Äôs worth regularly checking the board to see if something new‚Äîperhaps an ATM or even a Black Market storefront‚Äîis available to gather for and build.

You can‚Äôt have too much of anything

You will occasionally notice you have so many of one particular item that you feel convinced it makes sense to sell or dismantle them to make more space in your Warehouse. And sometimes you‚Äôll be right, but oftentimes you‚Äôll wish you hadn‚Äôt. Later quests can surprise you with a sudden need for both of those pointless footballs you found earlier, or you might think your Skill Enhancements no longer need the Cold Core Fragments now that you‚Äôre finding Crimson Core Fragments, but you‚Äôd be wrong. It‚Äôs always worth trying to add more space than delete stuff to create it.

Here‚Äôs how to mod weapons

Another element the game forgets to teach you is now to mod weapons, and while if you stumble on it you‚Äôll think it‚Äôs blatantly obvious, until you do it can be very frustrating. Adding the mods like grips, muzzles, scopes and magazines is not done when you‚Äôre crafting weapons, no matter how much it might look as though it should be. It‚Äôs done after, and it‚Äôs done just in your regular inventory. To adapt a weapon, open your inventory, left-click on the weapon, and a window will appear with all its details. There will be boxes for available mods, and you then need to drag and drop the mods from your inventory or Warehouse into these slots. That‚Äôs it. But it would have been nice if it had said so.

There really aren‚Äôt gamepad controls

It feels impossible that anyone would release a game in 2025 without gamepad controls, but that‚Äôs genuinely the case for Duckov. It‚Äôs fully mouse/keyboard, and it works splendidly that way, especially with all the shortcut keys. However, this is essentially a twin-stick shooter, and it would make so much sense to play it on your preferred controller! So far there hasn‚Äôt been any hint that adding gamepad options is a priority for the developers, and given it‚Äôs sold an extraordinary two million copies in two weeks on PC, it‚Äôs obviously not hindering anything. It does suggest console versions are a fair way off, however.



https://kotaku.com/escape-from-duckov-guide-tips-weapon-mods-storm-2000639589
